response.message: What made the difference for the new Arduino site?  Was it more effectively promoted than the original, or did Arduino just reach critical mass?  Or was it something else?

The first Arduino attempt had a couple of big problems, @Robert:
  • A bunch of folks committed to it and then never showed up.
  • The few questions that were asked were heavy into "electronics for beginners" territory - IOW, they were questions that could have been asked on an existing site (granted, many would've done poorly there due to being rather poorly asked, but that alone isn't a good reason to set up another site).
The new site quickly garnered a much larger volume of questions from folks doing stuff with Arduino - in short, it is much more of a cross-disciplinary site.

A bunch of us on Arduino.SE are trying to organize a contest for Arduino Day.

More information here -> http://meta.arduino.stackexchange.com/q/153/65

Thank you for the mention and the extended discussion about *Personal Finance & Money*. I'd also like to thank the entire *Money* moderator team and the community that made *Money* possible -- especially the experts who participate frequently.
@chris, your humility is admirable.  No one deserves more credit than you for the site's success - you've helped to build something great!

The kind folk of Money.SE didn't seem to like Joel's question: 

http://money.stackexchange.com/questions/29155/i-need-some-money-fast
I only want to learn how to be a banker. Could you help me please?

Those are some fantastic questions to answer, I've always wondered how certain things, such as gold/currency, come to have value! It seems like one of those questions which is complex but so simple at the same time!
You attract an audience and eventually a readership. We enjoy our visit and yours is certainly one of the most interesting websites on the internet!
